back: An ordered collection of numbers that has an accompanying set of mathematical operations.
The number of axes used to index the contents of a  mathematical object, such as a vector, matrix,  or tensor.
A single numerical value.
One of the numerical values that make up the vector.
The number of components a vector contains.

A (two-dimensional) plot that illustrates one or more  vectors as arrows that are typically specified by a location, which determines  the coordinates of the tail of the vector, and some specification of the  direction and magnitude of the vector. If no location is provided, then the  origin $(0,0)$ is used.

The starting point of a vector (the initial
point from which the displacement is measured).
The ending point of a vector (the point  at which the vector terminates after the specified displacement from the tail).

A (two-dimensional) scatter plot takes a sequence of two-dimensional data points $(x_0, y_0)$, $(x_1, y_1)$, $\ldots$, $(x_{n-1}, y_{n-1})$ and plots symbols (called markers) that represent the locations of the points in a rectangular region of a plane.
Data that is collected over time, usually at regular intervals. Each data point is associated with a timestamp indicating when the data was collected.

Most commonly used with categorical data for which each category has an associated quantity or measurement, a bar is drawn for each category, where the height or width of the bar is proportional to the associated quantity or measurement.

A vector of all zeros.
Ex: $\mathbf{0} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}^T$

A vector of all ones.
Ex: $\mathbf{1} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}^T$

A vector with all of its components equal to zero, except one element that is equal to one.
Ex: $\mathbf{e}_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}^T$

The sum of $n$ vectors \(\mathbf{a}\) and   \(\mathbf{b}\) is a vector \(\mathbf{a+b}\) such that any component $i$ of the   vector sum is the sum of the \(i\)th components of \(\mathbf{a}\) and   \(\mathbf{b}\); i.e. \(\mathbf{(a+b)}_i = a_i + b_i,~~i=0, 1,\ldots, n-1\).
Given a vector \(\mathbf{u}\) and a scalar \(\alpha\), define \(\alpha \mathbf{u}\) such that each component \(i\) of \(\alpha \mathbf{u}\) is given by \((\alpha \mathbf{u})_i = \alpha u_i\).

In NumPy, broadcasting occurs in operations involving two arrays of different shapes. The smaller array is broadcast across the larger array by repeating values in the smaller array in such a way that the shapes of the two arrays will match.

front:
component-wise multiplication (vectors)
or
Hadamard product (vectors)
or
Schur product (vectors)
back: Given \(n\)-vectors \(\mathbf{u}\) and \(\mathbf{v}\), the Hadamard product or Schur product is denoted \(\mathbf{u} \odot \mathbf{v}\) and is the \(n\)-vector given by component-wise multiplication of \(\mathbf{u}\) and \(\mathbf{v}\), \begin{equation*} \mathbf{u} \odot \mathbf{v} = \left[ u_0 v_0, ~~ u_1 v_1, ~~ \ldots,~~ u_{n-1} v_{n-1} \right]. \end{equation*}

Given \(n\)-vectors \(\mathbf{u}\) and \(\mathbf{v}\), the dot product or inner product is denoted \(\mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{v}\) or \(\mathbf{u}^T \mathbf{v}\) and is the scalar value given by multiplying corresponding components and summing them up: \begin{equation*} \mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{v} = \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} u_i v_i. \end{equation*}

For a mathematical object \(\mathbf{u}\) with an inner product operator \(\langle , \rangle\), the norm squared is denoted by \(\| \mathbf{u} \|^2\) and defined as \begin{equation*}   \| \mathbf{u} \|^2 = \langle \mathbf{u}, \mathbf{u} \rangle . \end{equation*}

For a mathematical object \(\mathbf{u}\) with an inner product operator \(\langle ~,~ \rangle\), the norm is denoted by \(\| \mathbf{u} \|\) and defined as \begin{equation*} \left \Vert \mathbf{u} \right \Vert = \sqrt{\langle \mathbf{u}, \mathbf{u} \rangle }. \end{equation*}
A vector \(\mathbf{v}\) is a unit vector if \(\| \mathbf{v} \| =1.\)

The distance between two \(n\)-vectors \(\mathbf{a}\) and \(\mathbf{b}\) is the norm of the difference between the vectors, \begin{equation*} d\left(\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{b}\right) = \left\| \mathbf{a} - \mathbf{b} \right\| = \left\|\mathbf{b} - \mathbf{a} \right\|. \end{equation*}

The correlation between \(n\)-vectors \(\mathbf{a}\) and \(\mathbf{b}\) is \begin{equation*} r= \frac{{\mathbf{a}} \cdot \mathbf{{b}} }{ \Vert\mathbf{{a}}\Vert \,\Vert\mathbf{{b}}\Vert}. \end{equation*}

The angle between \(n\)-vectors \(\mathbf{a}\) and \(\mathbf{b}\) is
  \begin{equation*} \theta = \cos^{-1} \left( \frac{{\mathbf{a}} \cdot \mathbf{{b}} }{ \Vert\mathbf{{a}}\Vert \,\Vert\mathbf{{b}}\Vert}\right). \end{equation*}
Vectors \(\mathbf{a}\) and \(\mathbf{b}\) are orthogonal if and only if \begin{equation*} \mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b} = 0. \end{equation*}

Vectors \(\mathbf{a}\) and \(\mathbf{b}\) are orthonormal if and only if \begin{equation*} \mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b} = 0 \end{equation*} and \begin{equation*}\| \mathbf{a} \| = \| \mathbf{b} \| = 1.\end{equation*}

Given \(n\)-vectors \(\mathbf{a}\) and \(\mathbf{b}\), the scalar projection of \(\mathbf{b}\) onto \(\mathbf{a}\) has magnitude equal to the length of the vector in the direction of \(\mathbf{a}\) that minimizes the error to \(\mathbf{b}\). The sign is positive if that component of \(\mathbf{b}\) is in the same direction as \(\mathbf{a}\) and negative if not. It is given by \begin{align*} \frac{ \mathbf{b} \cdot \mathbf{a}}{ \| \mathbf{a} \|}. \end{align*}

Let \(\mathbf{a}\) and \(\mathbf{b}\) be \(n\)-dimensional vectors. Then the vector projection of \(\mathbf{b}\) onto \(\mathbf{a}\), denoted \(\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{a}} \mathbf{b}\), is the vector in the direction of \(\mathbf{a}\) that minimizes the error to \(\mathbf{b}\). It is given by \begin{equation*} \operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{a}} \mathbf{b} = \frac{\mathbf{b} \cdot \mathbf{a} } { \left \Vert \mathbf{a} \right \Vert ^2} \mathbf{a}. \end{equation*}
